abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Allahabad Bypass Project
            (ABP) for India were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: non-completion of land acquisition and
            resettlement operations before the start of civil works was
            a major issue in the implementation of the ABP. Land
            required for the project should have been substantially
            acquired before the commencement of civil works to ensure
            that contractors are not impeded by insufficient land to
            progress the work. A well prepared detailed project report
            (DPR) is essential for proper implementation of a project.
            In the ABP, shortcomings in the DPR led to changes in the
            alignment of the carriageway and consequent revisions to the
            resettlement and rehabilitation plan. A well prepared DPR
            with more accurate information on the amount and ownership
            of the land required will have reduced the delays in land
            acquisition and resettlement. Measures that are to be
            implemented in a project should be clearly defined and be
            ready for execution upon the launching of the project. The
            corridor management component of the ABP suffered from a
            lack of clarity of the locations where the actions were
            supposed to be taken and also lack of specificity of the
            actions to be taken. More attention should be given to
            post-completion arrangements for the management and
            operation of an asset once the construction phase has
            finished. A clear plan should be in place for the handover
            of newly developed assets to the client. Use of the assets
            while some work is still in progress exposes the contractor
            and the client to litigation should accidents and damages
            occur. The use of fly ash in embankment construction has
            been proven to be technically viable and cost effective.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Allahabad Bypass
            Project for India are: a) to reduce transport constraints on
            national economic activity; and b) to improve institutional
            capabilities to manage road programs, assets and services on
            an increasingly commercial basis. The changes, involving
            exclusion of one of the project components and reallocation
            across components, will constitute a second order project
            restructuring. The restructuring is aimed towards utilizing
            the loan amount allocated for the corridor management
            component, which will otherwise remain unutilized. Moreover,
            by reallocating the loan amount to the bypass construction
            component, the marginal overrun in civil works can be met
            and achievement of development objective can be enhanced.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Allahabad Bypass Project (ABP) aims
            to (i) reduce transport constraints on national economic
            activity, and (ii) improve institutional capabilities to
            manage road programs, assets, and services on a more
            commercial basis. It is the third Bank loan to support the
            Government of  India's (GOI) National Highway
            Development Program (NHDP), which aims to upgrade 13,000 km
            of  core national highways network by 2007. The first two
            loans, namely the Third National Highway Project (TNHP)
            (rep. no. 20219)and Grand Trunk Road Improvement Project
            (GTRIP) (rep. no. 22169), were approved in June 2000 and
            June 2001, respectively. All three projects finance the
            upgrading of National Highway 2 between Delhi and Kolkata
            and support institutional strengthening actions.  There are
            three project components.   Component 1, bypass
            construction, funds the construction of  the 84.7 km bypass,
            which is located at the northern outskirts of  Allahabad
            City. The bypass will be an access controlled highway, with
            a 1 km bridge over the Ganga River. Toll plazas and rest
            areas will also be provided. Component 2 funds corridor
            management. Specifically, the component will fund the
            procurement of  private operators under performance based
            contracts for the operations and maintenance of
            Ahmedabad-Vadodra Expressway or selected national highway
            stretches, and the procurement and installation of  toll
            collection systems and automatic traffic management systems.
            Component 3, institutional strengthening, funds independent
            and periodic surveys of  road users and road sector
            stakeholders during the project period, to determine the
            level of  their awareness, involvement and satisfaction with
            the delivery, management and operation of  national highways
            by the National Highways Authority of India.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Allahabad Bypass Project :
            Environmental Assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Allahabad Bypass Project in India
            will improve highway transportation as part of the national
            policy to globalize its economy. The National Highways
            Authority of India (NHAI) is responsible for the
            development, maintenance and management of national highways
            in the country. However it is anticipated adverse
            environmental impacts will occur, thus mitigating measures
            stipulate the following. During construction operations -
            particularly if on temporarily acquired land - adequate
            traffic detours, storage and material handling should follow
            standard regulations, and topsoil from agricultural land
            will be preserved. Borrow pits shall not be dug continuously
            in a stretch, but rather re-developed at selected borrow
            location, while spoils shall be dumped with an overlay of
            stockpiled topsoil. To limit potential chemical hazards, the
            concrete foundation should contain a minimum cement content.
            Potential soil erosion at the high embankment portion on the
            north bank, should be contained by stone pitching.
            Vehicles/machinery, and equipment operation, maintenance and
            refueling activities shall be implemented so that spillage
            of fuel, and lubricants does not contaminate the Ganga river
            flows. Non-bituminous wastes will be dumped in borrow pits
            covered with a layer of excavated topsoil. The sewerage
            system for the construction workers' camp shall be
            designed, built and operated so that no pollution to ground,
            or adjacent watercourses occurs. On completion of the works,
            all temporary structures shall be cleared away.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Allahabad Bypass Project :
            resttlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Allahabad Bypass Project includes
            alignments passing entirely through plain agricultural
            fields, and through rural settings within a number of
            villages, an influence area where agriculture is the
            mainstay of local populations, mostly farmers belonging to
            small, and marginal groups, and includes a variety of crops
            grown in the region. This Resettlement Action Plan (RAP)
            assesses the negative social impacts of the project, and
            suggests socioeconomic rehabilitation measures, in order to
            improve, or at least restore, the living conditions of
            project affected people (PAP). Based on socioeconomic, and
            census surveys, and in consultation with stakeholders, the
            RAP determines the following measures to minimize adverse
            social impacts resulting from project implementation. The
            project will seek to redesign intersections as possible, to
            avoid unnecessary loss of land, and structures, while
            service roads will be constructed to provide easy access,
            but under strict enforcement of parking, and traffic safety
            measures to discipline the traffic flow. Compensation will
            be provided at replacement values for loss of land, and
            physical structures, which includes the provision of
            drainage facilities; loss of crops, trees, and orchards,
            will be compensated based on estimated market values, while
            irrigation units will be replaced by the project; a
            double-story shopping complex should be built on nearby
            Government land, to accommodate demolished shops and
            businesses, and alternative income restoration will be
            considered; training will be provided to promote self
            employment opportunities, in line with the Government's
            poverty alleviation schemes; vulnerable groups will be given
            special consideration for their resettlement/rehabilitation
            needs, on priority bases; and, public awareness campaigns,
            monitoring, and grievance mechanisms will be established to
            ensure the adequate resettlement process.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Allahabad Bypass Project in India
            will improve highway transportation as part of the national
            policy to globalize its economy. The National Highways
            Authority of India (NHAI) is responsible for the
            development, maintenance and management of national highways
            in the country. However it is anticipated adverse
            environmental impacts will occur, thus mitigating measures
            stipulate the following. During construction operations -
            particularly if on temporarily acquired land - adequate
            traffic detours, storage and material handling should follow
            standard regulations, and topsoil from agricultural land
            will be preserved. Borrow pits shall not be dug continuously
            in a stretch, but rather re-developed at selected borrow
            location, while spoils shall be dumped with an overlay of
            stockpiled topsoil. To limit potential chemical hazards, the
            concrete foundation should contain a minimum cement content.
            Potential soil erosion at the high embankment portion on the
            north bank, should be contained by stone pitching.
            Vehicles/machinery, and equipment operation, maintenance and
            refueling activities shall be implemented so that spillage
            of fuel, and lubricants does not contaminate the Ganga river
            flows. Non-bituminous wastes will be dumped in borrow pits
            covered with a layer of excavated topsoil. The sewerage
            system for the construction workers' camp shall be
            designed, built and operated so that no pollution to ground,
            or adjacent watercourses occurs. On completion of the works,
            all temporary structures shall be cleared away.
